## Example: The Melbourne Collaborative Cohort Study (MCCS)

In this tutorial we will again use the MCCS data (mccs.dta) but for this practical we will deal with more complex scenarios that often need to be considered when building an imputation model.

There are 2 scenarios that we will explore when performing multiple imputation:

1. The analysis model of interest includes a nonlinear association between the confounding variable, vitamin C, and the log odds of high cholesterol.

2. The analysis model of interest includes an interaction between the variables heaviest weight and dietary red meat intake.

Below is a description of the variables in the MCCS dataset that we will use for this practical. Please note that for this practical we will ignore the auxiliary variables considered in practical 1 but remember that, in practice, it is important to include auxiliary variables in your imputation model.

## Scenario 1 â€“ nonlinear association in analysis model

The research question of interest is (as for practical 1) whether _alcohol intake_ is related to the _risk of high cholesterol_, and in particular, whether this relationship remains once potential confounders have been adjusted for. The analysis model of interest is a multivariable logistic regression but differs from practical 1 as the model now includes the extra variable _vitc_sq_ to allow for a nonlinear association between vitamin C levels and the log-odds of high cholesterol. The new analysis model is given below:

$$
highchol \sim binomial(1, p)
$$

$$
logit(p) = \alpha + \beta_1 alc_any + \beta_2 age + \beta_3 ethnic_1 + \beta_4 ethnic_2 + \beta_5 ethnic_3 + \beta_6 physic_1 + \beta_7 physic_2 + \beta_8 physic_3 + \beta_9 cig_1 + \beta_10 cig_2 + \beta_{11} dpb + \beta_{12} vitc + \beta_{13} vitc_sq
$$
where _highchol_ is an indicator for having high cholesterol (defined as total cholesterol concentration >6.2mmol/L), _alc_any_ is an indicator for any alcohol consumption (compared with a reference group of no alcohol consumption), ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£1, ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£2 and ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£3 are indicators for the participantâ€™s country of birth being the UK/Malta, Italy and Greece respectively (Australia/NZ/Other is the reference group), ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£1, ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£2 and ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£3 are indicators for low, moderate and high levels of physical activity (compared to the reference of no physical activity), ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–1 and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–2 are indicators for current and former smoker (compared with never smoker), ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ is the continuous measure of diastolic blood pressure (mmHg), and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ is the continuous measure of the level of vitamin C and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  is the square of vitamin C levels derived from ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£.

### Since we have already investigated the missing data in practical 1 (which is something that we should always do before conducting any analysis), we will simply look again at the missing data patterns, in particular, the percentage of participants with missing data for _vitc_.

```{r 1a}
summary(mccs) ## missing data in alc_any, physic, vitc, hvy_wgt, hypr_flg, dbt_flg
md.pattern(mccs[,c("alc_any", "physic","vitc")])
```


### Carry out a complete case analysis using the logistic regression model of interest (remember to include the _vitc_sq_ term and tell Stata that some of the variables in the model are factor variables e.g. using the i. notation).

```{r 1b}
logitfit <- glm(highchol ~ alc_any + age + ethnic + physic+cig +dbp + vitc + I(vitc^2), 
                data = mccs, family = "binomial")
summary(logitfit)

## odds ratios and 95% CI
exp(cbind(OR = coef(logitfit), confint(logitfit)))
```


### Passive imputation

(i) Impute the missing values in the analysis variables using fully conditional specification applied just to the variables in the analysis model but without including _vitc_sq_ in your imputation model. This approach is commonly termed â€œpassive imputationâ€.
[As stated in the previous practical, continuous variables should be imputed using linear regression, binary variables using logistic regression and ordinal variables using ordinal logistic regression.]

```{r 1c1}
summary(mccs[, -c(1, 10:17)])
midata1 <- mccs[, -c(1, 10:17)]
out1 <- mice(midata1, m = 50, method = c("", "logreg", "", "", "polr", "", "", "norm"), maxit = 5, seed = 210115)
out1 

```


(ii) Carry out the analysis of interest using the mi estimate command. Since we have not imputed any values for the variable, ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ , you will need to derive the values for this variable by taking the squared values of the imputed vitamin C levels. This can be done using the mi passive command.
Compare the MI estimate for the exposure of interest, ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘, and the confounder vitamin C (remember to look at the coefficients for ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  ) with the estimates obtained from the complete case analysis in part (b) (for ease you can write the coefficients in Table 2, provided below).
[Note, you will need to use the eform option within mi estimate to obtain odds ratios.]

### 

(i) Now repeat the passive imputation approach in part (c) but use predictive mean matching for vitamin C (sometimes referred to as â€œimproved passive imputationâ€). Predictive mean matching is an ad hoc method of imputing missing values, where imputed values are sampled only from the observed values (i.e. observed values of vitamin C for our example).
(ii) Carry out the analysis of interest using the mi estimate command. Since we have not imputed any values for the variable, ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ , you will need to derive the values for this variable by taking the squared values of the imputed vitamin C levels. This can be done using the mi passive command.
Compare the MI estimate for the exposure of interest, ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ and the confounder vitamin C (remember to look at the coefficients for ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  ) with the estimates obtained in parts (b) and (c).

###

Now repeat the imputation including ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  in the imputation model and re-run the mi estimate command. [Note, when you re-run the imputations you will need to re-open the MCCS data and recalculate the required ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  variable.] The inclusion of the non-linear term in the imputation model is a variant of the original â€œJust Another Variableâ€ method (the original approach applied this method within multivariate normal imputation).
The â€œJust Another Variableâ€ approach (see - White IR, Royston P, Wood AM. Multiple imputation using chained equations: Issues and guidance for practice. Statistics in Medicine, 2011;30(4):377-99) imputes both ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  as if ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  was â€œjust another variableâ€ to be imputed rather than being determined from ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£. The obvious disadvantage is that the imputed values of ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  are not equal to the square of the corresponding imputed values for ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£.
Compare the MI estimates for ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘£h_ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘, ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘  with those from the complete case analysis from part (b) and the imputation analyses obtained in parts (c) and (d).

## Scenario 2 â€“ interaction term in analysis model

For scenario 2 the analysis model of interest is a multivariable logistic regression that includes the additional variables heaviest weight and dietary red meat intake as well as interaction term between these two variables (and excludes the nonlinear term for vitamin C), see below for details:
hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–hğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘œğ‘œğ‘œğ‘œ~ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œ(1, ğ‘ğ‘)
ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘œğ‘œğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£(ğ‘ğ‘) = ğ›¼ğ›¼ + ğ›½ğ›½1ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘£ğ‘£_ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ›½ğ›½2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ›½ğ›½3ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£1 + ğ›½ğ›½4ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£2 + ğ›½ğ›½5ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£3 + ğ›½ğ›½6ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£1 + ğ›½ğ›½7ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£2 + ğ›½ğ›½8ğ‘ğ‘hğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£3 + ğ›½ğ›½9ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–1 + ğ›½ğ›½10ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘–2 + ğ›½ğ›½11ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ + ğ›½ğ›½12ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘£+ ğ›½ğ›½13hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ + ğ›½ğ›½14ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ + ğ›½ğ›½15hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ âˆ— ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£
where hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ âˆ— ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ represents the interaction term between the continuous variable heaviest weight, hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£, and the binary variable indicating high dietary red meat intake consumption, ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£.
a. We begin by looking again at the missing data patterns, and in particular, the percentage of participants with missing data for hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£.
b. Carry out a complete case analysis using the logistic regression model of interest (remember to include the interaction term between heaviest weight and dietary red meat intake using the Stata c.X1##i.X2 code).
c. Impute the missing values in the analysis variables using fully conditional specification applied just to the variables in the analysis model but without including the interaction. [Again continuous variables should be imputed using linear regression, binary variables using logistic regression and ordinal variables using ordinal logistic regression.]
d. Carry out the analysis of interest using the mi estimate command, remembering to include the interaction term in the analysis model.
Compare the MI estimate for the estimates for hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ (i.e. main effects and the interaction term) obtained from the complete case analysis in part (b) (for ease you can write the coefficients in Table 3, provided below).
e. Now repeat the imputation including hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ âˆ— ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ in the imputation model using the â€œJust Another Variableâ€ method, and carry out the analysis of interest. Compare the estimates with those obtained in parts (b) and (d).
Note, as for the nonlinear scenario with the squared term for vitamin C, again the disadvantage of the â€œJust Another Variableâ€ approach is that the imputed value of say hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ âˆ— ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ will not be the same as the value calculated from multiplying the imputed values of hğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘_ğ‘¤ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£ and ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘£.
f. An alternative approach for imputing interaction terms is to impute one of the variables in the interaction e.g. X1 (which can be any data type) separately at different levels of the second variable in the interaction e.g. X2 (which must be a categorical variable). This can be a useful approach as long as there arenâ€™t too many categories for X2 and there are a reasonable number of observations within each category. By imputing separately by levels of X2 allows the relationship between X1 and Y to differ according to the groups of X2, hence allows for the interaction.
Note, this approach can only be used if X2 has no missing data and is categorical.

For our example impute the variables with missing data separately for those with high and low red meat consumption using the by()option in mi impute in Stata. Compare the estimates with those obtained in parts (b), (d) and (e).

## Summary

The key take home message for this practical is that we can bias our results if there is not congeniality between the imputation model and analysis model, that is, if the form of the relationship between the variables in the analysis model is not reflected in the imputation model. This means that if there are nonlinear and/or interaction terms in the analysis model, we must consider nonlinear and/or interaction terms in the imputation model.
There has been further work in this area (Bartlett JW et al. Multiple imputation of covariates by fully conditional specification: Accommodating the substantive model. Statistical Methods in Medical Research, 2014) where Bartlett and colleagues have developed another method for carrying out multiple imputation in the presence of nonlinear and interaction terms called â€œsubstantive model compatibility full conditional specificationâ€, Stata function SMC-FCS (The Stata Journal, Vol 15(2), pg437-456). Details available at:- www.missingdata.org.uk
